title: The Battle of Actium from The Story of Caesar and Cleopatra

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of wool and silk, slit and double interlocking tapestry weave.

artist_display:
After a design by Justus van Egmont (1601–1674)
Woven at the workshop of Willem van Leefdael (1632–1688)
Flanders, Brussels
description: During the winter of 42–41 BCE, Cleopatra became pregnant with twins. The following year, however, Antony returned to Rome and prepared a long-awaited campaign against the Parthians. Yet Octavian failed to support the endeavor. Disappointed, Antony left Italy and sailed to Alexandria, where he renewed his relationship with Cleopatra. Meanwhile, the triumvirate disintegrated, and Octavian rose to power in Rome. Eventually Antony broke off relations with Octavian, and in 31 BCE civil war broke out again. The decisive sea battle was fought at Actium, a promontory in northern Greece. As depicted in the tapestry, the Egyptian fleet was destroyed by the Romans, and Antony fled to Egypt in Cleopatra’s boat. In 30 BCE, Octavian invaded Egypt. Rather than surrender to his enemy, Antony committed suicide. A few days later, Cleopatra followed his example. Their tragic deaths are not included in this suite.
medium_display: Wool and silk, slit and double interlocking tapestry weave
inscriptions:
Marked and signed: Brussels city mark; G·V·LEEFDAEL
Inscribed: CLEOPATRA·AB / INNIMICIS·IN / MARI·INVADITVUR (Cleopatra is attacked by her enemies at sea)
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Chauncey McCormick and Mrs. Richard Ely Danielson
publication_history: Koenraad Brosens, ed., Christa C. Mayer Thurman, gen. ed., European Tapestries in the Art Institute of Chicago, exh. cat., [exhibition: "The Divine Art: Four Centuries of European Tapestries in the Art Institute of Chicago"] (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2008) 138-165, cat. 19N.
exhibition_history:
Art Institute of Chicago, Regenstein Hall, The Divine Art: Four Centuries of European Tapestry, November 1, 2008–January 4, 2009.

Art Institute of Chicago, Deering Family Galleries, March 28, 2018-May 28, 2019.
provenance_text: Possibly the Villalonga family, Mallorca, to 1914 at the latest; Charles Deering (died 1927), Marycel, Sitges, Spain, by 1914; by descent to his daughters Mrs. Chauncey McCormick (born Marion Deering, died 1965) and Mrs. Ely Danielson (born Barbara Deering, died 1982); given to the Art Institute, 1944.

input: The Battle of Actium from The Story of Caesar and Cleopatra
